docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: PATIENT trials of new treatments, long a crown jewel of American medical science, are increasingly being conducted overseas, a number of prominent researchers say.

headline.main: For More Drugs, First Test Is Abroad

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The most difficult case i ever had?'' Ruth Macklin pauses, momentarily - and most uncharacteristically - at a loss for words as she thinks back over the hundreds she has considered in a decade as ethicist in residence at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and its affiliated hospitals in New York City.

byline.original: By Katherine Bouton; Katherine Bouton is an editor of The Times Magazine

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: For the first time, researchers have been able to cure patients with chronic hepatitis B, a devastating and often progressively debilitating liver disease that afflicts more than a million Americans and is the ninth leading cause of death worldwide.

headline.main: Drug Is Found to Cure Some With a Deadly Liver Disease

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: A small biotechnology company based in Seattle has taken the lead in the race to introduce a class of drugs that build up the body's defense against infections. Analysts say the drugs could prove the most important product of genetic engineering yet.

headline.main: Business Technology;   The Race for Anti-Infection Drugs
